page.title: 15Trees,flowers in Leverton
page.content: In the original Domesday survey it was recorded that there were 110 acres of "underwood".It is doubtful if we could manage to record 10 acres in 1985. There are some patches of standard trees but Dutch elm disease disposed of many large specimens which are only slowly being replaced.Several of the trees are quite ancient but healthy and make a contrast to the flat landscape.Wild flowers,however,are becoming rarer as modern verge cutting equipment is used to keep the roadsides clear.Very few are allowed to seed and consequently only low growing plants are succeeding.Cow parsley,hogweed,vetches,trefoils and bindweeds can still be found but much of the flag iris has now vanished. Small areas of ground are left natural and wild plants can be found there if you are prepared to look carefully.
